bibl.title: Draft of letter from the Secretary of War to David A. Reed, March 18, 1932

div1.p: The Secretary of War recommends denying the claim of A.S. Pinto, as presented in Senate Bill No. 206.

div1.head: Draft of letter from the Secretary of War to David A. Reed, March 18, 1932
div1.opener:
COPY FOR COL. TRUBY
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Draft only, submitted for signature of Secretary of War - March 18, 1932.
Re Pinto
WAR DEPARTMENT
Washington
Honorable David A. Reed,
Chairman, Committee on Military Affairs,
United States Senate,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Senator:
div1.p:
Careful consideration has been given to the Senate bill No. 206,
Seventy-second Congress, first session, “to recognize the high public
service rendered by Doctor A. S. Pinto, and the bravery displayed by him
in connection with the discovery of the cause and means of transmission
of yellow fever,” upon which the views of the War Department were re-
quested by your indorsement of reference dated February 24, 1932.

By act of Congress approved February 28, 1929, the Secretary of
War is authorized and directed “In special recognition of the high pub-
lic services rendered and disabilities contracted in the interests of
humanity and science as voluntary subjects for the experimentations dur-
ing the yellow fever investigations in Cuba” to publish annually in the
Army Register a roll of honor, and the officers and men whose names were
to be placed on the said roll were specifically stated in that act. The
part taken by them in the experiments is fully set forth in the reports
of the Yellow Fever Board which are published in Senate Document 822,
Sixty-first Congress, third session.

Dr. Alva S. Pinto served as Contract Surgeon in the Army from
October 3, 1898, to April 4, 1901. He was stationed at Columbia Barracks,
near Havana, Cuba, from December 2, 1898, to October 10, 1900. He had
no other service in Cuba. When he left Cuba he went to the Philippines
for duty, and served there as Captain and Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Volun-
teers, until February 1, 1903.

The investigations referred to in the act of February 26, 1929,
were made by a board of which Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U.S.A., was
president, appointed by the Secretary of War May 24, 1900 (SO No. 122,
AGO that date). The board assembled in Cuba in June 1900, and conducted
several series of experiments to discover the agency for the transmission
of the disease. The first series was conducted during the period August 2
to some time in October, 1900, while Major Reed was necessarily absent in
the United States. Upon his return to Cuba he instituted a second and
more elaborate series which began November 20, 1900, at an experimental
case called Camp Lazear. A third series was instituted the following
fall (1901).

Prior to the investigations by this board various theories had
been suggested as to the means by which yellow fever is communicated from
man to man, among them whether by bodily contact, by contact with the
excreta of the sick, or by the bite of an infected mosquito. Dr. Carlos
Finlay, of Havana, had several years before advanced the postulate that
the mosquito was at least one agency of transmission; but numerous ex-
periments made by him on that line had been entirely negative and his
theory in August 1900 was generally discredited by the profession. Never-
theless, there was sufficient speculative or conjectural basis to warrant
further experiments either to confirm it on the one hand, or to exclude it
from further consideration on the other. To that end, on August 11, 1900,
Dr. Lazear, a member of the board, made the first experiment, consisting
of mosquito bites on 9 persons, including himself and Dr. Pinto. The names
of the other 7 are not shown on the records and are now unknown. All of
those, like the Finlay tests, were unsuccessful (see page 18, Senate
Document 822, above), as no adequate measures had then been taken to
assure the conditions, which were later discovered, necessary for mosquito
transmission of this disease. In other words, at the time these tests
were made they were under a theory not generally believed, and those who
submitted to them had no serious apprehension of danger therefrom. But
within the next four weeks three cases of the disease followed subsequent
mosquito bites under conditions which convinced Major Reed that the mos-
quito was a transmitting agent, and led to the second series of more
rigorous experiments beginning November 20, 1900, which left no doubt in
the premises.

Dr. Pinto took no part in those later experiments, having left Cuba
on October 10. What he did was to allow himself on August 11 to be bitten
by a mosquito, when mosquito transmission was a discredited theory and the
bite thereof was believed by most to offer no hazard. In point of fact,
the mosquito which bit him was perfectly harmless, and as shown by his
medical history he suffered no disability whatever from the bite. The
words of the bill referring to his “high public service” and “the bravery
displayed by him in incurring disabilities in the interest of humanity”
are unsupported by any facts of record in the Department.

Those who took part in the experiments of November 20 and later, by
submitting themselves to the bites of infected mosquitoes, after the theory
of mosquito transmission under certain conditions had been practically
determined as outlined in Major Reed's preliminary report, did, however,
consciously and most heroically put their lives in hazard, and in the view
of the Department stand on an entirely different festing. The act of
February 28, 1929, was intended to honor them for their bravery and re-
ward them for the suffering consequent thereon. To include others within
its scope whose bravery was in no sense conspicuous and who incurred no
suffering and no disabilities whatever would be to disparage and cheapon
the honors and rewards heretofore conferred in this regard.

Dr. Pinto's share in the experiments which have been of such great
benefit to mankind was, for the reasons hereinbefore indicated, of little
or no value. Certainly it was of no greater value than that of each of
the 7 unknown who were also bitten by harmless mosquitoes on August 11.
-3-
To pass this law, singling him out for special recognition, would at once
pave the way for similar measures in behalf of the other 7, without any
means of identifying or limiting the persons claiming to be among them.
Nor would it be unlikely, considering how these things go, for a whole
multitude to spring up, claiming similar recognition who, by reason of
service in Cuba at the time the experiments were going on, were bitten by
mosquitoes, or had yellow fever, or perhaps attended yellow fever patients,
but who contributed in no real sense to the epoch-making experiments which
have brought this dread disease under control.

In the Department's view the door to those extraordinary honors
should not be opened to those who rendered no extraordinary service and
made no measurable contribution to the work, but should admit only the
three categories of persons covered in the existing law (or their depend-
ents) namely, First, Members of the Yellow Fever Board; Second, Those who
offered themselves for experiment by mosquito or blood inoculation and
suffered attacks of yellow fever in consequence; Third, Those who took part
in the infected bedding experiments.

Doctor Pinto's services as a contract surgeon and medical officer
were wholly creditable to him, but, as in the case of thousands of others,
in no wise beyond the call of duty, and do not entitle him in the opinion
of the Department to the distinction and annuity proposed by S. 206. It
is recommended, therefore, that that bill be not favorably considered.
